result.value:
A manuscript has been submitted to bioRxiv.

---

If you like this software, you can give us a [star](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/stargazers) to boost our visibility! All direct contributions are also welcome. Feel free to post a new [issue](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/issues) or clone the repository and create a [pull request](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pulls) with a new branch. For an even more interactive participation, check out the [discussions](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/discussions) and the [the Contributors License Agreement](misc/CLA.md).

Further information on the development process can be found [here](docs/installation.md).

---

- Empirical library and fully predicted library search - Label free quantification - DIA multiplexing | Platform | Empirical lib | Predicted lib | | :---------------- | :------: | :----: | | Thermo .raw | ✅ | ✅ | | Sciex .wiff | ✅ | ✅ | | Bruker .d | ✅ | ⚠️ | > ⚠️ **Predicted libraries with Bruker .d data**
Alltough search is possible, alphaDIA's feature-free search takes a long time with fully predicted libraries. We are still evaluating how to better support fully predicted libraries.

**Please cite:** > **AlphaDIA enables End-to-End Transfer Learning for Feature-Free Proteomics**
> Georg Wallmann, Patricia Skowronek, Vincenth Brennsteiner, Mikhail Lebedev, Marvin Thielert, Sophia Steigerwald, Mohamed Kotb, Tim Heymann, Xie-Xuan Zhou, Magnus Schwörer, Maximilian T. Strauss, Constantin Ammar, Sander Willems, Wen-Feng Zeng, Matthias Mann
> [biorxiv.org](https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.05.28.596182v1) alphaDIA is part of the alphaX ecosystem: - [alphaPept](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphapept) - [alphaTims](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphatims) - [alphaPeptDeep](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphapeptdeep) - [alphaRaw](https://github.com/MannLabs/alpharaw) - [alphaBase](https://github.com/MannLabs/alphabase) - [directLFQ](https://github.com/MannLabs/directlfq)
In case of issues, check out the following:
See the [HISTORY.md](HISTORY.md) for a full overview of the changes made in each version.

# Installation

AlphaDIA can be installed on Windows, macOS and Linux. Please choose the preferred installation:

* [**One-click GUI installation:**](#one-click-gui-installation) Choose this installation if you only want the GUI and/or keep things as simple as possible.

* [**Pip installation**](#pip-installation)This version allows you to use alphaDIA as a package within your conda environment. You will only have access to the search engine backend and the command line but not the GUI.

* [**Developer installation:**](#developer-installation) This installation allows to modify alphaDIA's source code directly. Generally, the developer version of alphaDIA outperforms the precompiled versions which makes this the installation of choice for high-throughput experiments.

* [**Docker installation:**](#docker-installation) Choose this for running alphaDIA in a Docker container, which is useful if you want to run it in a cloud environment.

* [**Slurm installation:**](#slurm-cluster-installation) Choose this for running alphaDIA on a research cluster with Slurm.

## One-click GUI installation
Currently available for **MacOS** and **Windows**.
You can download the latest release of alphaDIA [here](https://github.com/Mannlabs/alphadia/releases/latest).

* **Windows:** Download the latest `win-x64` build. Save it and double click it to install. If you receive a warning during installation click *Run anyway*.
* **MacOS:** Download the latest `darwin-arm64` build. Please note that alphaDIA currently requires an ARM based M1/2/3 processor for the one-click installer. Save the installer and open the parent folder in Finder. Right-click and select *open*. If you receive a warning during installation click *Open*. If you want to use `.raw` files on Thermo instruments alphaRaw is required, which depends on Mono. A detailed guide to installing alphaRaw with mono can be found [here](https://github.com/MannLabs/alpharaw#installation).

As of now, **Linux** users need follow the steps for the
[developer installation](#developer-installation) in order to use the GUI.

## Pip installation
If you want to use alphaDIA as a python library (e.g. for importing it into Jupyter notebooks) or only use the command-line interface,
you can install alphaDIA via `pip`.

### 1. Prerequisites
Please make sure you have a valid installation of conda or miniconda.
We recommend setting up miniconda as described on their [website](https://docs.conda.io/projects/miniconda/en/latest/).

If you want to use `.raw` files on Thermo instruments alphaRaw is required, which depends on Mono.
A detailed guide to installing alphaRaw with mono can be found [here](https://github.com/MannLabs/alpharaw#installation), a short version is given
[below](#2-installing-mono).

### 2. Setting up the environment

It is highly recommended to use a conda environment for the installation of alphaDIA.
This ensures that all dependencies are installed correctly and do not interfere with other packages.
```bash
conda create -n alphadia python=3.11 -y
conda activate alphadia
```

### 3. Installing alphaDIA
Finally, alphaDIA and all its dependencies can be installed by
```bash
pip install "alphadia[stable]"
```
We strongly recommend using the `stable` version, which has all dependencies fixed,
for reasons of reproducibility and integrity.

Alternatively, use
`pip install alphadia`, which comes with less version constraints. This is not recommended, but may be useful to avoid
version clashes if alphaDIA is imported as a library into a defined python requirement.
Note however, that this "loose" version might be affected e.g. by breaking changes of third-party dependencies.

Finally, run `alphadia -v` to check if the installation was successful;
`alphadia -h` will give you a list of command-line options.


## Developer installation
AlphaDIA can be installed in editable (i.e. developer) mode. This allows to fully customize the software and even modify the source code to your specific needs. When an editable Python package is installed, its source code is stored in a location of your choice.

Make sure you have a conda environment and Mono installed for reading `.raw` files as described [here](https://github.com/MannLabs/alpharaw#installation).

See also the [developer guide](developer_guide.md) for more information on how to contribute to alphaDIA.

### 1. Setting up the repository

Navigate to a folder where you would like to install alphaDIA and
 download the alphaDIA repository. This creates a subfolder `alphadia` in your current directory
```bash
cd ~/work/search_engines
git clone git@github.com:MannLabs/alphadia.git
cd alphadia
```

Optionally, to get the latest features, switch to the `development` branch and pull the most recent version
```bash
git switch development
git pull
```

### 2. Installation: backend
Set up a conda environment and activate it as described [here](#2-setting-up-the-environment).

Use pip to install alphaDIA, using the `development` tag to install additional packages required for development only
```bash
pip install -e ".[stable,development]"
```
If you need less strict versions for third-party dependencies, use `pip install -e ".[development]"`.

Note: by using the editable flag `-e`, all modifications to the alphaDIA source code folder are directly reflected when running alphaDIA. Note that the alphaDIA folder cannot be moved and/or renamed if an editable version is installed.


### 3. Installation: GUI (optional)

If you want to use or extend the GUI, please install NodeJS as described on their [website](https://nodejs.org/en/download).

Install all frontend packages using npm
```bash
cd gui
npm install
```
Note that this gui install only works if the conda environment is called "`alphadia`",
unless the "envName" variables in `profile.js` are adjusted.

The GUI can then be started by typing
```bash
npm run dev
```

## Docker Installation
The containerized version can be used to run alphaDIA e.g. on cloud platforms.
It can be used to run alphaDIA for multiple input files, as well as for single files only
(trivial parallelization on computing clusters).

Note that this container is not optimized neither for performance nor size yet, and does not run on Apple Silicon chips
(M1/M2/M3) due to problems with mono. Also, it currently relies on the input files being organized
in a specific folder structure.

### 1. Setting up Docker
Install the latest version of docker (https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/).

### 2. Prepare folder structure
Set up your data to match the expected folder structure:
- Create a folder and store its name in a variable, e.g. `DATA_FOLDER=/home/username/data; mkdir -p $DATA_FOLDER`
- In this folder, create 4 subfolders:
  - `library`: put your library file here, make it writeable for any user (`chmod o+rw *`)
  - `raw`: put your raw data here
  - `output`: make this folder writeable for any user: `chmod -R o+rwx output` (this is where the output files will be stored)
  - `config`: create a file named `config.yaml` here, with the following content:
```yaml
library: /app/data/library/LIBRARY_FILE.hdf
raw_path_list:
  - /app/data/raw/RAW_FILE_1.raw
  - /app/data/raw/RAW_FILE_2.raw
  - ...
output_directory: /app/data/output
```
  Substitute `LIBRARY_FILE` and `RAW_FILE` with your respective file names, but preserve the `/app/data/../` prefix.
  The rest of the config values are taken from `default.yaml`, unless you overwrite any value from there
  in your `config.yaml`.

### 3. Start the container
```bash
docker run -v $DATA_FOLDER:/app/data/ mannlabs/alphadia:latest
```
After initial download of the container, alphaDIA will start running immediately. Alternatively, you can run an interactive session with
`docker run -v $DATA_FOLDER:/app/data/ -it mannlabs/alphadia:latest bash`

### 4. (Advanced) Build the image yourself
If you want to build the image yourself, you can do so by
```bash
docker build -t alphadia-docker .
```
and run it with
```bash
docker run -v $DATA_FOLDER:/app/data/ --rm alphadia-docker
```

## Slurm cluster Installation

### 1. Set up environment
Check if conda is available on your cluster. If not, install it, or, if provided, load the corresponding module, e.g.
`module load anaconda/3/2023.03`. You might be asked to run `conda init bash` to initialize conda.

Create and activate a new conda environment
```bash
conda create -n alphadia -y
conda activate alphadia
```
### 2. Installing mono
Install mono to support reading proprietary vendor formats like Thermo `.raw` files.


Install python into your new environment
```bash
conda install python=3.11 -y
```
Then install mono by
```bash
conda install mono=6.12.0.182 -c anaconda -y
```

Test that mono is correctly installed by running
```bash
mono --version
```

The output should look something like this:
```
Mono JIT compiler version 6.12.0.182 (tarball Mon Jun 26 17:39:19 UTC 2023)
Copyright (C) 2002-2014 Novell, Inc, Xamarin Inc and Contributors. www.mono-project.com
	TLS:           __thread
	SIGSEGV:       altstack
	Notifications: epoll
	Architecture:  amd64
	Disabled:      none
	Misc:          softdebug
	Interpreter:   yes
	LLVM:          supported, not enabled.
	Suspend:       hybrid
	GC:            sgen (concurrent by default)
```


### 3. Installing alphaDIA

Install alphaDIA using pip:
```bash
pip install "alphadia[stable]"
```
Afterward, verify the alphaDIA installation by running:
`alphadia --version` which should output the current version.

### Notes on running alphaDIA as part of automated workflows
AlphaDIA is designed to be run in a headless mode. In case of an error, a nonzero exit code is returned.
A exit code of 127 indicates that there was an unknown error. All other nonzero exit codes pertain to
'business errors', i.e. those caused most likely by user input (data and/or configuration).

Further details on such errors can be found in the `events.jsonl` file in the `.progress` folder(s) of the output directory.

### Slurm script example
You can find an example of a Slurm script here: [./tests/e2e_tests/e2e_slurm.sh](./tests/e2e_tests/e2e_slurm.sh).

AlphaDIA can be installed on Windows, macOS and Linux. Please choose the preferred installation:

* [**One-click GUI installation:**](#one-click-gui-installation) Choose this installation if you only want the GUI and/or keep things as simple as possible.

* [**Pip installation**](#pip-installation)This version allows you to use alphaDIA in your python environment (provided e.g. by conda). You will only have access to the search engine backend and the command line but not the GUI.

* [**Developer installation:**](docs/installation.md#developer-installation) This installation allows to modify alphaDIA's source code directly. Generally, the developer version of alphaDIA outperforms the precompiled versions which makes this the installation of choice for high-throughput experiments.

* [**Docker installation:**](docs/installation.md#use-the-dockerized-version) Choose this for running alphaDIA in a Docker container, which is useful if you want to run it in a cloud environment.

* [**Slurm installation:**](docs/installation.md#slurm-cluster-installation) Choose this for running alphaDIA on a research cluster with Slurm.

Currently available for **MacOS** and **Windows**.
You can download the latest release of alphaDIA [here](https://github.com/Mannlabs/alphadia/releases/latest).

* **Windows:** Download the latest `win-x64` build. Save it and double click it to install. If you receive a warning during installation click *Run anyway*.
* **MacOS:** Download the latest `darwin-arm64` build. Please note that alphaDIA currently requires an ARM based M1/2/3 processor for the one-click installer. Save the installer and open the parent folder in Finder. Right-click and select *open*. If you receive a warning during installation click *Open*. If you want to use `.raw` files on Thermo instruments alphaRaw is required, which depends on Mono. A detailed guide to installing alphaRaw with mono can be found [here](https://github.com/MannLabs/alpharaw#installation).

As of now, **Linux** users need follow the steps for the
[developer installation](docs/installation.md#developer-installation) in order to use the GUI.

If you want to use alphaDIA as a python library (e.g. for importing it into Jupyter notebooks) or only use the command-line interface,
you can install alphaDIA via `pip`.

For any Python package, it is highly recommended to use a separate, as otherwise dependancy conflicts can occur with already existing packages. We generally recommend [miniconda](https://docs.anaconda.com/free/miniconda/).

Finally, alphaDIA and all its dependencies can be installed by
```bash
pip install "alphadia[stable]"
```
We strongly recommend using the `stable` version, which has all dependencies fixed,
for reasons of reproducibility and integrity.

Alternatively, use
`pip install alphadia`, which comes with less version constraints. This is not recommended, but may be useful to avoid
version clashes if alphaDIA is imported as a library into a defined python requirement.
Note however, that this "loose" version might be affected e.g. by breaking changes of third-party dependencies.

Finally, run `alphadia -v` to check if the installation was successful;
`alphadia -h` will give you a list of command-line options.

---

| Platform | Empirical lib | Predicted lib | | :---------------- | :------: | :----: | | Thermo .raw | ✅ | ✅ | | Sciex .wiff | ✅ | ✅ | | Bruker .d | ✅ | ⚠️ | > ⚠️ **Predicted libraries with Bruker .d data**
Alltough search is possible, alphaDIA's feature-free search takes a long time with fully predicted libraries. We are still evaluating how to better support fully predicted libraries.

AlphaDIA was developed by the [Mann Labs at the Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry](https://www.biochem.mpg.de/mann) and is freely available with an [Apache License](LICENSE.txt). External Python packages (available in the [requirements](requirements) folder) have their own licenses, which can be consulted on their respective websites.

---

<!-- Release notes generated using configuration in .github/release.yml at main -->

## What's Changed
### Bug fixes
* BUG optimization lock, fix #347 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/348
* Allow correct processing of empty files by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/349
### Other Changes / unlabeled
* Bump alphaX dependencies by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/346
* Remove old release workflow by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/345
* Bump version: 1.8.0 → 1.8.1 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/350
* Change modlayout default by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/352
* release 1.8.1 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/351


**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/compare/v1.8.0...v1.8.1

result.description:
<!-- Release notes generated using configuration in .github/release.yml at main -->

## What's Changed
### Bug fixes
* BUG in timstof transpose function by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/307
* BUG multiplexing fails due to missing column by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/314
* BUG max-lr not used correctly by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/311
### New Features
* Add unknown mods by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/291
* Add automatic calibration by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/293
* timing manager by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/306
* Multiplex spectral library by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/292
* FEAT enable selection of alternative peptdeep models by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/312
### Other Changes / unlabeled
* Selecting classifier version by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/282
* MS2 Optimizer by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/283
* Getting the right classifier version in the optimizer by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/287
* Transfer learning documentation by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/266
* make error handling automation-friendly by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/279
* raise on missing checkpoint path by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/290
* add parameters to stat.tsv by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/302
* Fix slurm install instructions by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/294
* fix test case data by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/298
* #299: add slurm e2e script by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/300
* 296 reduce alphadia output by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/297
* Calibrate optimization lock only during optimization by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/301
* extend transfer-learning to include mobility by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/303
* New dynamic lock with RT proportion by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/316
* New dynamic optimization lock by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/309
* Calibrate relevant subset in dynamic lock by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/317
* Make optimization configurable by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/318
* Refactor parameter proposal by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/319
* Fix timing manager by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/321
* Make convergence configurable by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/322
* Make fragment calibration configurable by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/323
* New RT convergence criteria by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/320
* Fix optimizer plotting by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/325
* Refactor search parameter optimization by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/324
* allow definition of target RT as fraction by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/328
* fix error with config by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/327
* Use batch index at optimum by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/329
* Additional convergence criterion by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/330
* Refactor convergence rules by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/331
* make automatic default by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/336
* updated documentation by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/334
* Proceed if insufficient precursors by @odespard in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/333
* feat: save stats of transfer learning to disk by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/338
* Fix incorrect mobility outputaccumulator by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/337
* Refactor Finetune Manager  by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/310
* Adapt to new release workflow by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/326
* bump version to 1.8.0 by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/342
* GUI fixes by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/343
* Release 1.8.0 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/344

## New Contributors
* @odespard made their first contribution in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/282

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/compare/v1.7.2...v1.8.0

## What's Changed
### Bug fixes
* Bugfixes in GUI by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/275
* Fail transparently for failed output accumulation by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/278
* Fix out of bounds segfault by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/272
### Other Changes / unlabeled
* Development by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/199
* Simplified pyinstaller script by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/265
* change plotting to use seaborn by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/267
* 268 divisionbyzeroerror by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/269
* Update Badges in README.md by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/271
* update debug notebook by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/274
* Cleanup unused numba functions by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/273
* release 1.7.2 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/276


**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/compare/v1.7.1...v1.7.2

## What's Changed
### Bug fixes
* fix warnings for scheduler step and early stopping by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/252
* FIX remove numba strict true by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/259
* FIX Overwrite old profile by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/255
### New Features
* FEAT Change transferlearning metrics datastructure by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/232
* FEAT modular FDR core implementation by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/229
* Include raw name in transfer lib by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/254
### Other Changes / unlabeled
* 230 basic linting by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/231
* 230 basic linting rule e by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/233
* 230 basic linting rule f by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/235
* 230 basic linting rule f remove unused by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/236

* 230 basic linting rule i2 by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/244
* Add conda to docu by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/245
* Add test split by @mo-sameh in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/243
* #230: ruff rule B905: add strict keyword to zip by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/246

* #261 install MANIFEST.in in docker container by @dnusinow in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/262

## New Contributors

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/compare/v1.7.0...v1.7.1

result.description:
## What's Changed
* Development by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/199
* Fix uname issue by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/201
* DOCS Improved installation and method section by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/203
* Add readthedocs link and badge by @mschwoer in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/206
* DOCS update readme by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/210
* release 1.6.2 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/204
* CHORE fixed alphabase requirement by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/193
* FIX fasta for Bruker by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/213

result.description:
## Installation
```
conda create -n alpha
conda install python=3.8
cd some/folder/to/store
git clone git@github.com:MannLabs/alphadia.git
pip install -e .
```
Afterwards the GUI can be downloaded and extracted.

## What's Changed
* Bug fixes by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/40
* FIX memory leak in GUI by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/39
* GUI Improvements by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/41
* Release 1.3.1 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/42


**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/compare/v1.3.0...v1.3.1

result.description:
## Installation
Unfortunately, there is still no one click installer for the search engine itself.
```
conda create -n alpha
conda install python=3.8
cd some/folder/to/store
git clone git@github.com:MannLabs/alphadia.git
pip install -e .
```

Afterwards the GUI can be downloaded and extracted.

## What's Changed
* Electron GUI setup by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/28
* Major cleanup by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/29
* Major cleanup, preparation for v1.2.0 by @GeorgWa in https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/pull/30


**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia/compare/v1.1.0...1.2.0

result.description:
Please follow the developer installer instructions. When cloning, set the version tag as branch:
```
git clone https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia.git --branch v1.0.1
```
For simple extraction workflows, use the reference provided by `alphadia extract -h`:
```
      _   _      _         ___ ___   _   
     /_\ | |_ __| |_  __ _|   \_ _| /_\  
    / _ \| | '_ \ ' \/ _` | |) | | / _ \ 
   /_/ \_\_| .__/_||_\__,_|___/___/_/ \_\
           |_|              version: 1.0.1

Usage: alphadia extract [OPTIONS] OUTPUT_LOCATION

  Extract DIA precursors from a list of raw files using a spectral library.

Options:
  -f, --file PATH            Raw data input files.
  -l, --library FILE         Spectral library in AlphaBase hdf5 format.
  --fdr FLOAT                False discovery rate for the final output.
                             [default: 0.01]
  --keep-decoys BOOLEAN      Keep decoys in the final output.  [default:
                             False]
  --config-path FILE         DO NOT TOUCH - Default config yaml. If not
                             specified, the default config will be used.
  --config-update-path FILE  Config yaml which will be used to update the
                             default config.
  --config-update TEXT       Dict which will be used to update the default
                             config.
  --neptune-token TEXT       Neptune.ai token for continous logging.
  --neptune-tag TEXT         Neptune.ai tag for continous logging.
  --figure-path DIRECTORY    If specified, directory will be used to store
                             calibration figures.
  -h, --help                 Show this message and exit.
```
result.name: v1.0.1

result.description:
First pre release, follow Developer installer instructions. When cloning, set the version tag as branch:
```
git clone https://github.com/MannLabs/alphadia.git --branch v1.0.0
```
For simple extraction workflows, use the reference provided by `alphadia extract -h`:
```
      _   _      _         ___ ___   _   
     /_\ | |_ __| |_  __ _|   \_ _| /_\  
    / _ \| | '_ \ ' \/ _` | |) | | / _ \ 
   /_/ \_\_| .__/_||_\__,_|___/___/_/ \_\
           |_|              version: 1.0.0

Usage: alphadia extract [OPTIONS] OUTPUT_LOCATION

  Extract DIA precursors from a list of raw files using a spectral library.

Options:
  -f, --file PATH            Raw data input files.
  -l, --library FILE         Spectral library in AlphaBase hdf5 format.
  --fdr FLOAT                False discovery rate for the final output.
                             [default: 0.01]
  --keep-decoys BOOLEAN      Keep decoys in the final output.  [default:
                             False]
  --config-path FILE         DO NOT TOUCH - Default config yaml. If not
                             specified, the default config will be used.
  --config-update-path FILE  Config yaml which will be used to update the
                             default config.
  --config-update TEXT       Dict which will be used to update the default
                             config.
  --neptune-token TEXT       Neptune.ai token for continous logging.
  --neptune-tag TEXT         Neptune.ai tag for continous logging.
  --figure-path DIRECTORY    If specified, directory will be used to store
                             calibration figures.
  -h, --help                 Show this message and exit.
```
result.name: v1.0.0

result.value:
Please make sure you have a valid installation of conda or miniconda.
We recommend setting up miniconda as described on their [website](https://docs.conda.io/projects/miniconda/en/latest/).

If you want to use `.raw` files on Thermo instruments alphaRaw is required, which depends on Mono. A detailed guide to installing alphaRaw with mono can be found [here](https://github.com/MannLabs/alpharaw#installation).

Click *Run Workflow* to start the search and see the progress.


---

This guide will show you how to perform your first search using the One-click GUI. ### 1. Prerequisites Make sure you have installed the GUI using the one-click installer. To verify your installation, open alphaDIA and make sure that the `BundledExecutionEngine` is selected.

For the first search we will be using a spectral library to search 60SPD bulk HeLa samples on the Orbitrap Astral. Download the test samples and save them: [HeLa library](https://datashare.biochem.mpg.de/s/Uw2yfNSbApfPpTk), [RAW files].(https://datashare.biochem.mpg.de/s/339jg5HtGrwLwDN)
Import the library `.hdf` file and select the thre `.raw` files. You can select a human `.fasta` file for reannotation but it's generally not recommended for empirical spectral libraries.

Although alphaDIA is highly customizable, we will only specify a limited number of settings here. Go to the *Search* settings and make the following changes:
* Number of candidates: 5
* MS1 Tolerance 4ppm
* MS2 Tolerance 7ppm
Select an output folder where the search progress and the final results should be saved.
